entries.title: on afterKeyDown
entries.body:
times_24_biuosdceon afterKeyDown

times_12_biuosdcetimes_12_biuosdceCalled when a key is pressed.
You can use the functions monaco_9_biuosdcekeyChar()times_12_biuosdce,  monaco_9_biuosdceshiftKey()times_12_biuosdce,  monaco_9_biuosdceoptionKey()times_12_biuosdce, 
and monaco_9_biuosdcecommandKey()times_12_biuosdce, to determine which key(s) where pressed.

monaco_9_biuosdcekeyRepeated()times_12_biuosdce can be used to see if the key event comes from
the key having been held down.

Examples:
monaco_9_biuosdce
on afterKeyDown
    if keyChar() is "i" and not shiftKey() and \
            optionKey() and not commandKey() then
        answer "you pressed option-i"
    else if keyChar() is "U" and shiftKey() and \
            not optionKey() and not commandKey() then
        answer "you pressed shift-u"
    end if
end afterKeyDown

entries.title: on afterKeyUp
entries.body:
times_24_biuosdceon afterKeyUp

times_12_biuosdcetimes_12_biuosdceCalled when a key is pressed and released.
You can use the functions keyChar(), shiftKey(), optionKey(), and
commandKey(), to determine which key(s) where pressed.

Examples:
monaco_9_biuosdce
on afterKeyUp
    if keyChar() is "i" and not shiftKey() and \
            optionKey() and not commandKey() then
        answer "you pressed option-i"
    else if keyChar() is "U" and shiftKey() and \
            not optionKey() and not commandKey() then
        answer "you pressed shift-u"
    end if
end afterKeyUp

entries.title: on closeBackground
entries.body:
times_24_biuosdceon closeBackground

times_12_biuosdcetimes_12_biuosdceWhen you go to a different card, if the card belongs to a different background, the closeBackground message will be sent. (You're leaving one background and going to another).

Examples:
monaco_9_biuosdce
-- in a background's script
on closeBackground
    answer "you have left this background"
end closeBackground

entries.title: on closeCard
entries.body:
times_24_biuosdceon closeCard

times_12_biuosdcetimes_12_biuosdceMessage sent upon leaving a card.

Because messages continue up the hierarchy until they are handled, you can also respond to closeCard in a stack script.

Examples:
monaco_9_biuosdce
-- in a card's script
on closeCard
    answer "you have left this card"
end closeCard

entries.title: on closeField
entries.body:
times_24_biuosdceon closeField

times_12_biuosdcetimes_12_biuosdceSent when the user clicks on a field to select it, types text into the field, and then de-selects the field.

If the browse tool is active, this message will be sent by the following:
When typing text into a field, click outside the field
When typing text into a field, press Enter
When typing text into a field, go to a different card

See also: monaco_9_biuosdceopenFieldtimes_12_biuosdce and monaco_9_biuosdceexitFieldtimes_12_biuosdce.

The message is sent to the target field and travels upward to the current card as usual.

Examples:
monaco_9_biuosdce
-- in a field's script

on closeField
    -- do a simple check of what the user just typed
    if not "@" in the target then
        put "not a e-mail address" into cd fld "status"
    else
        put "" into cd fld "status"
    end if
end closeField

entries.title: on exitField
entries.body:
times_24_biuosdceon exitField

times_12_biuosdcetimes_12_biuosdceSent when the user clicks on a field to select it, does not type text into the field, and then de-selects the field.

If the browse tool is active, this message will be sent by the following:
When a field is selected, click outside the field
When a field is selected, press Enter
When a field is selected, go to a different card

It's possible for exitField to be sent to the field more than once if some of the above actions happen at the same time.

See also: monaco_9_biuosdceopenFieldtimes_12_biuosdce and monaco_9_biuosdcecloseFieldtimes_12_biuosdce.

The message is sent to the target field and travels upward to the current card as usual.

Examples:
monaco_9_biuosdce
-- in a field's script

on openField
    show cd btn "indicateCurrentlyEditingField"
end openField

on closeField
    hide cd btn "indicateCurrentlyEditingField"
end closeField

on exitField
    hide cd btn "indicateCurrentlyEditingField"
end exitField

entries.title: on idle
entries.body:
times_24_biuosdceon idle

times_12_biuosdcetimes_12_biuosdceSent repeatedly to the current card. Can be used for a game loop.

(Note that to terminate a script that is being called repeatedly, 
you can change to the button or field tool.)

To get faster idle calls, at the expense of heavier cpu usage,
use
monaco_9_biuosdceset the idlerate to "faster"times_12_biuosdce

entries.title: on mouseDoubleClick
entries.body:
times_24_biuosdceon mouseDoubleClick

times_12_biuosdcetimes_12_biuosdceRemember that scripts are only run when you're in the Browse
tool (hand-shape). Create a button and type the example below.
Now when you choose the browse tool and double-click the
button, your code will run.

Examples:
monaco_9_biuosdce
on mouseDoubleClick
    answer "you double-clicked this button."
end mouseDoubleClick

entries.title: on mouseDown
entries.body:
times_24_biuosdceon mouseDown

times_12_biuosdcetimes_12_biuosdceRemember that scripts are only run when you're in the
Browse tool (hand-shape). Called whenever the mouse is 
pressed down onto the object. Create a button and type the 
example below. Now when you choose the browse tool and 
click the button, your code will run.

Examples:
monaco_9_biuosdce
on mouseDown
    answer "code is running."
end mouseDown

entries.title: on mouseEnter
entries.body:
times_24_biuosdceon mouseEnter

times_12_biuosdcetimes_12_biuosdceRemember that scripts are only run when you're in the Browse tool
(hand-shape). Called whenever the mouse enters the object.

entries.title: on mouseLeave
entries.body:
times_24_biuosdceon mouseLeave

times_12_biuosdcetimes_12_biuosdceRemember that scripts are only run when you're in the Browse tool
(hand-shape). Called whenever the mouse leaves the object.

entries.title: on mouseUp
entries.body:
times_24_biuosdceon mouseUp

times_12_biuosdcetimes_12_biuosdceRemember that scripts are only run when you're in the Browse tool
(hand-shape). Called whenever the mouse is clicked. To be precise,
when the mouse is pressed down onto the object, and released on
the same object. Create a button and type the example below. 
Now when you choose the browse tool and click the button, 
your code will run.

Examples:
monaco_9_biuosdce
on mouseUp
    answer "code is running."
end mouseUp

entries.title: on mouseWithin
entries.body:
times_24_biuosdceon mouseWithin

times_12_biuosdcetimes_12_biuosdceCalled repeatedly when the cursor is inside the object.
You can use the mouseloc() function to get the position of the 
cursor. This can be used to create drag/drop effects.

(Note that to terminate a script that is being called repeatedly, 
you can change to the button or field tool.)

entries.title: on openField
entries.body:
times_24_biuosdceon openField

times_12_biuosdcetimes_12_biuosdceSent to a field, when text is first selected in it.

See also: monaco_9_biuosdcecloseFieldtimes_12_biuosdce and monaco_9_biuosdceexitFieldtimes_12_biuosdce.

Examples:
monaco_9_biuosdce
-- in a field's script

on openField
    -- place default text in the field when you tab over to it...
    put "abc" into the target
end openField
